html:
A digression on multi-user, read-only access, and standoffs. 

AI is a user like you. It may want to annotate or enrich your text and overlap your own links. 

You can end up with interlaced wikilinks:

[[(1) Aaa [[(2) Bbbb (1)]] Ccc ]](2) 

This cannot be represented in Markdown

author.name: Bruno Winck
author.description:
The Personal Knowledge Management Guy. 🤣
Founder @PKMCollective and @Kneaver.
Travelling Software Architect.
#PKMChat Host
@brunowinck@mastodon.social

html:
Text:
(1) Aaa (2) Bbbb (3) Ccc (4) 
Outside text:
1st link goes from 1 to 3,
2nd link goes from 2 to 4

AFAIK only @codexeditor implemented that pattern.

It's also useful if the user B has only read access to what user A wrote. Markers can be set & the links kept in B's area

author.name: Linus
author.description: thought & craft · ex @replit @hackclub @dormroomfund

html: Willy-nilly spraying the GPT-3 next-token prediction powder on your tool/product is a recipe for disaster outside of narrow workflows where text is the asset being produced. In all other cases, don't ship the API to the user. Text generation is not the product! Reasoning is.

author.name: Linus
author.description: thought & craft · ex @replit @hackclub @dormroomfund

html: Text, like code, is a liability, not an asset.\n\nAn organization should strive to own as little text as necessary to express their information and accomplish tasks.

author.name: Linus
author.description: thought & craft · ex @replit @hackclub @dormroomfund

html:
This means text generation in the best LLM products will be an implementation detail, as much as backend APIs are for current SaaS:

- Parsing nuanced, contextual action items out of transcriptions or human input
- Translating between soft, ill-defined data fmts and natural lang

author.name: Linus
author.description: thought & craft · ex @replit @hackclub @dormroomfund

html: A vanishingly small slice of knowledge work has the shape of text-in-text-out (copywriting/Jasper). The real alpha is not in generating text, but in using this new capability and wrapping it into jobs that have other shapes.

author.name: Linus
author.description: thought & craft · ex @replit @hackclub @dormroomfund

html: The fact that LLMs generate text is not the point. LLMs are cheap, infinitely scalable black boxes to soft human-like reasoning. That's the headline! The text I/O mode is just the API to this reasoning genie. It's a side effect of the training paradigm.

author.name: Linus
author.description: thought & craft · ex @replit @hackclub @dormroomfund

html:
Small rant about LLMs and how I see them being put, rather thoughtlessly IMO, into productivity tools. 📄

TL;DR — Most knowledge work isn't a text-generation task, and your product shouldn't ship an implementation detail of LLMs as the end-user interface

https://t.co/N1NJoKzUqA https://t.co/eEedO8Zf00
